instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> burning??
threads.message:
Hey everyone,

Not sure if this is expected behaviour.

I replaced the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>) chip because <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was <5V. I measured all resistors related and they came back fine.

After replacing <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> the system had a fan spin and I placed it back into the system for testing, but to my surprised the flux that I hadn't cleaned started smoking right where <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> is at!
The system keeps running without issues and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and PPDCIN is stable at their expected voltages, but I don't think <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> is supposed to get this hot, or is it?

Just gotta be sure before I give it back and it burns a house down ;)

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> burning??
threads.message: Dead <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> buck killed switching mosfets. Compare resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with known good and make sure that it isn't partially short, then if it's ok replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> for good measure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> burning??
threads.message:
No (semi-)short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, will replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>.

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> burning??
threads.message:
3 weeks ago, wow!

Anyways the flux around <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> is still smoking away.

I gotta wonder if its normal for those mosfets to get this hot? I mean the system is running alright and boots into the system

Could it be a broken replacement <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> burning??
threads.message: Not normal, bad ISL or bad soldering. Check diode mode at the gate of <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> to see if there is actually a connection to the ISL.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> burning??
threads.message:
With errors like this you always hope it isnt your soldering, this is one of those cases where it indeed was my soldering.

The traces had continuity across them and the connections looked good, however giving a good sweep with some solder across them fixed the issue.

Thanks for your time, my bad!
